UgxY50e-orWEOOMBbIh4AaABAg.text: If you can learn a piece decently within one week, then that's about your level. So you can experiment with different pieces until you find your level. The usual gauge is: If you can sightread the entire piece without too much difficulty, then that is your level.

Ugy_b19lfoO8Em69f7N4AaABAg.text: @pinkie35 That's a really tough question.  However, players of "La Campanella" may understand, as it has many large skips.  The most important thing to remember is to help your hand to release by allowing the least amount of tension possible.  Start very slowly, rotating back and forth, and slowly increase, making sure you maintain evenness.  Eventually it will start feeling much more natural and you will be able to accommodate this.  Let me know if that helps :)

UgihVT58c_XfO3gCoAEC.text:
Do Doom in Vulkan - OpenGL performance isn't telling the full story at all.
ROTR is a gameworks title, it's not a legit DX12 game since it is just a bolt on and actually causes performance loss

AMD wins in literally every other DX12 game, AOS, Hitman,Warhammer,TImespy,Quantum,GOW, and In Doom Vulkan  the 1060 is nowhere near the RX480

in DX11 the 1060 is about 6-7% faster on average vs a non throttling RX480
in DX12 the RX480 is 15% faster on average if it's not being throttled

RX480 is cheaper and overall better
1060 is better for DX11 and uses lower power

When making your choice factor these things in
UgihVT58c_XfO3gCoAEC.author: LowCal Legend

UgjznZHXmQaWhXgCoAEC.text:
I'm genuinely torn. The 1060 is an immediate improvement over the RX480 in most applications benched here. I'm not going to use an entry level card to power 4k or even 1440p, so I don't give a shit about that. These are 1080p cards, make no mistake. 

However, there is the question of Vulkan and async computing, which favors AMD cards more. Presumably, if more games over the course of the next two years implement Vulkan and async, the RX480 will benefit the most. 

Hmmmmm. Maybe I should just go whole hog and forget this nonsense by buying a GTX 1070. That would solve all my 1080p60fps issues for at least a year and a half. But I'd rather not blow all that money. I'd rather wait for the true single card solution for 4k, and purchase a new monitor at that point.

Argh decisions decisions.... I'll just have to see what MSi can do for the 1060 and what Sapphire can do for the RX480. If the 1060 factory overclocks like a beast, that might be the deciding factor. From what I've heard, the RX480's just don't have a lot of overhead. 

I guess it's going to be another long month.

So it'll be 299 or higher making it at least 50-100+ bucks more than a 480.  Are they really even in the same bracket for comparison at this point? I just don't know if we should be pairing them as rivals. Thats a pretty hefty price difference at this level for a budget minded gamer that the 480 targets. If I was willing to buy at the 300-330 price point I would have got a 390 and not waited for the 480 due to sheer impatience. I'm glad I waited for other reasons but it was a major factor for me, a barrier so to say. 

From what I'm seeing in benchmarks so far, for most current or slightly older titles the 1060s raw power beats the 480. However DX12 the 480 is doing better for most titles, and   we know damn well that Vulkan games the 480 should do better.  Look at the boost Vulkan gave the 480 for DOOM. 

Then to consider the 1060 can't SLI while I can go get another 480, crossfire and be more on the heels of the 1080, when I decide the upgrade is warranted to do

Why would you focus testing on DX11 when the future of gaming is DX12 and Vulkan?  I can't really see game devs continuing to release new games using DX11.  If you are gonna spend the cash for a mainstream card wouldn't you want maximize your dollar and future proof the purchase?  

The fact that RX480 seems to get better at higher resolutions seems to me like it is the better value, since 1080p is giving way to 3k and 4k gaming.  Also the Vulkan benchmarks show the RX480 making 20%-30% performance gains and the 1080 getting only 3%-5% gains.  I think this comes down to DX12 and Vulkan being heavily based on AMD's Mantle.  Team Red is making a pretty compelling case. 

However if you can wait I would say wait for Vega and Volta, since the current gen is just a die shrink of the last gen with a couple tweaks.  Honestly my 970 seems just fine until I upgrade my monitors to 5k or jump into VR.  Spring of 2017 doesnt seem so far away.

I'd choose the RX 480.

Reasons:
1) wipes the floor with the GTX 1060 in Doom/Vulkan (1080p: +25%, 1440p: +32%)
2) more future proof: better support for future games and next gen APIs
3) offers significantly more VRAM (again more future proof)

5) AMD's open source driver support and FreeSync software

7) costs..... less!

Uggl5exLinkaUXgCoAEC.text:
I'd pick the 1060. lower power draw and temps and I'm betting much better over clocks because Pascal>Polaris. Also all the features Nvidia cards come with. Shadowplay, etc. 

Also better DX11 support because AMD has monkeys developing their DX11 drivers. A Fury X is almost 3 tflops faster than a 980ti yet can barely beat it in real world tests.. that should tell you something. 

Also as far as APIs go, it's way to early to bank on which manufacturer will excel at what API. Nvidia does well in both. AMD benefits the most because as mentioned earlier, they can't develop a decent DX11 driver so the gains are much more prominent for them. That being said, there isn't even a handful of next gen API games out. I'd wait till next gen of cards to make that choice.

Regardless, both are doing well and AMD is finally stepping up their shit with an architecture that won't set your house on fire. I'd pick Nvidia even if there is a little premium for the reasons above but in the end you can't go wrong with either chip manufacturer at the moment.
Uggl5exLinkaUXgCoAEC.author: Rushaoz

Josh - Nice technique and I'll listen to more of your lessons.  
In your video, when you say the word "flex," you are showing "extension" (straightening) of a finger or fingers rather than "flexing" the finger(s).  "Flexing" is to have the finger or finger tips curl or bend toward the keyboard or palm of hand. 
 Have you, by the way, heard of a technique called, "the purl"?

UgxSxfP-i3b6p_AMHat4AaABAg.text: Just one thing, when hanging your hand down loosely from the shoulders, the fingers do not curve as extreme as you suggested when talking about the 2+3 trill. Thus tugging in finger 3-5 like you suggest is not their natural position, but it certainly avoids the shaking associated with them being held above the keys. And their is nothing inherently wrong with them giggling along during the 2-3 trill. But I agree that it looks more elegantly the way you do it.  If the trill is short however, I would rest the fingers above the keys and let them giggle along so they are ready for their next task. Just a thought.
UgxSxfP-i3b6p_AMHat4AaABAg.author: Thomas Gunther

UghL9zbYnngbgHgCoAEC.text: After working through various technical difficulties of my own I have become convinced that the root of all technical problems is a lack of finger strength. When you ask a finger to do something that it is not strong enough to do, the OTHER fingers around it will do strange and unexpected things in an attempt to help the struggling finger. They will tense up or 'fly away' or perhaps your wrist will break or you'll drop a shoulder or hunch your back or tense up in some other way. This is why when you start working on a new piece you will sometimes find your fingers doing unexpected and bizarre things. Things you've never seen them do before. I think the problem is not with the finger(s) that are tense or flying away, but with some other finger which is too weak for what is required at that point in the piece. You can see this same kind of problem in all other physical activities (sports) where technique breaks down because of weakness. This is why all sports have strength and conditioning programs during the off season. They understand that strength is the foundation for good technique in any physical endeavor. Find your weakness, fix your weakness, and your technical problems will go away. The stronger you are the easier it is to relax. If you are weak you won't be able to relax. As you get stronger you will discover that it is easier to find your muscles and relax them and still play.
UghL9zbYnngbgHgCoAEC.author: Don

UggrRfKIGNGUongCoAEC.text: Are you sure the wobbling exercise really makes the hand more neutral? From experiments on both myself and students, I find lifting fingers is a panic reflex to stop the whole palm falling down through a droopy and inert finger. Wobbling makes my finger stand up into more life, not more neutral. I also use conscious finger lifting to empower the standing finger into more action, before letting them dangle back down (while keeping the standing finger active and alive). I find this kind of conscious finger lifting is ironically the quickest cure for unwanted lifting. Once the playing fingers are keeping the hand open, with more action, the panic reflex vanishes. Drooping after producing tone is the underlying fault, which causes the panic.
UggrRfKIGNGUongCoAEC.author: cziffra1980

UgywsJ4797I7irCblyx4AaABAg.text: If you put dried kale in the oven with just oil, the kale won't shrink as much. After it comes out of the oven, then lightly sprinkle with sea salt.
